87953: Flash Conscription.author: OmegaSerris
87953: Flash Conscription.text_parsed:
Oh, they missed a very awesome possibility here. Rather than just tacking on unflavorful lifelink here, why not Valor Made Real? I know lifelink has been done on cards before, but here it seems forced and just an excuse to up the CMC. Take a look:

Flash Conscription
Instant
Untap target creature and gain control of it until end of turn. That creature gains haste until end of turn. If was spent to cast Flash Conscription, the creature may block any number of creatures this turn.

Look at Fight to the Death and tell me that this version wouldn't work as a card. It could be used as either a Threaten or a flash Pariah with the potential of killing a SECOND creature (or more). Oh the combat tricks that card could have granted. Ah well... maybe one day.

87954: Leave No Trace.author: Kryptnyt
87954: Leave No Trace.text_parsed:
@ultratog
Everyone will rate cards differently, and for different reasons. This card has fantastic art and flavor text that makes a point, and some people like that, you know? that brings the average up.
Other considerations for a card would be casual play, block constructed, limited play, how it was in the standard format it was in. I'm sure not everyone who has rated this card has actually put it in a deck at one point. There are probably a couple of people who treasure the card for various reasons, such as memorable situations of using it. Hell, someone may have rated it down because they got demolished by it!
Personally, I think a 5 is not "I have to put it in all of my decks." That's because I make a shitton of decks. Some people, on the other spectrum, feel differently because they add and remove cards from one deck they've had for forever. The rating system is very open ended! So don't facepalm the voters, mate!

87954: Leave No Trace.author: DacenOctavio
87954: Leave No Trace.text_parsed:
A friend of mine runs Zedruu, the Great-hearted in our local EDH meta. He builds for himself a pillow fort of enchantments in the vein of Ghostly Prison and Solitary Confinement, and uses cards such as Form of the Dragon, Transcendence, and Statecraft to nuke opposing players by donating to them. Out of my Numot, the Devastator deck, my arsenal of enchantment hate cards includes this.

Another friend of mine runs Bruna, Light of Alabaster. For him, I always search up this and Tormod's Crypt. The biggest targets are Righteous Authority and Steel of the Godhead. He concedes to that on the spot. It's wonderful building a deck full of silver bullets when you have 63 slots to work with.

87955: Mortipede.author: Gaussgoat
87955: Mortipede.text_parsed:
An interesting card, a 4/1 beater who comes equipped with a Lure that can be activated at will.

A nice easy trick is throw Regeneration on him, that way you can keep the opponent tied up every turn.

His high power makes him a nice target for any ability which gives trample, Rancor for example. The built in Lure also makes him get extra milleage out of strength increasing effects like Giant Growth or Howl from Beyond.

Lots of fun, not the greatest card in the world, but combo potential up the wazoo.

4/5

87956: Surge of Zeal.author: DarkCerberusXX
87956: Surge of Zeal.text_parsed:
No no no, you're all missing the point of an instant. The point of an instant is that when your enemy overextends, you change the game and cut their legs out from under them for it. IE:

You play something like a red Tim or two, or another creature with a tap effect.
They attack knowing you can't tap and use the ability yet and won't chump block.
Surge of Zeal.

That's how and why this can be situationally better than Burst of Speed.

87962: Shred Memory.author: OmegaSerris
87962: Shred Memory.text_parsed:
I think this is suffering from cycling's reputation. I know a few people that won't even look at a card if it has a cycling ability. One of them flips out when I put the cycling land in my EDH decks. I like it throwing out cards that won't help my current situation in the game but his come back is "then put better cards in the deck" which is kind of short sighted because a land is a land, cycling or not. If I take them out, I draw less of them (usually early game when I need them.)

So anyways, this is so much better than that. How many two drops in black alone could save you turn 5? Shrivel and Marsh Casualties can save you from an Overrun of tokens next turn. A hard to kill fatty can get Cruel Edict'ed not to mention the 47 other "destroy" spells in black at that cost. Should you need a combo piece or some other win card, that costs other than two, you can always pull out Demonic Tutor.

That isn't even mentioning the card's effect, should you need to stop a few annoying re-animators instead. Or other cards in other colors, like popping out a counterspell to make your opponent sweat about which spells to play next turn or some beefy 2 cost green blocker.

So I guess my point is that this card is pretty damn good at getting you that answer you need, NOW. Costly? Sure, but aren't all choices in Magic more expensive than not having options?
87962: Shred Memory.text_posted:
I think this is suffering from cycling's reputation. I know a few people that won't even look at a card if it has a cycling ability. One of them flips out when I put the cycling land in my EDH decks. I like it throwing out cards that won't help my current situation in the game but his come back is "then put better cards in the deck" which is kind of short sighted because a land is a land, cycling or not. If I take them out, I draw less of them (usually early game when I need them.)

So anyways, this is so much better than that. How many two drops in black alone could save you turn 5? [autocard]Shrivel[/autocard] and [autocard]Marsh Casualties[/autocard] can save you from an [autocard]Overrun[/autocard] of tokens next turn. A hard to kill fatty can get [autocard]Cruel Edict[/autocard]'ed not to mention the 47 other "destroy" spells in black at that cost. Should you need a combo piece or some other win card, that costs other than two, you can always pull out [autocard]Demonic Tutor[/autocard]. 

That isn't even mentioning the card's effect, should you need to stop a few annoying re-animators instead. Or other cards in other colors, like popping out a counterspell to make your opponent sweat about which spells to play next turn or some beefy 2 cost green blocker.

So I guess my point is that this card is pretty damn good at getting you that answer you need, NOW. Costly? Sure, but aren't all choices in Magic more expensive than not having options?

87962: Shred Memory.author: Brawler_1337
87962: Shred Memory.text_parsed:
I'm considering this for my Karador EDH deck. So far, the only graveyard hate I have is Bojuka Bog. While that's all great, it's limited to sorcery speed. While this doesn't get rid of the whole graveyard, it does let you get rid of another reanimator deck's best four targets, which could make a difference.

But when you're not facing a reanimator deck, this card still has value because of Transmute. My deck can tutor ten cards with this card so far, and I can always add more. You can make it a flexible five mana tutor that thins your deck by two by transmuting for Demonic Tutor or Diabolic Intent (which is more along the style of my deck). You can tutor for any creature with Eladamri's Call or Altar of Bone. You can grab Blood Artist, Qasali Pridemage, or Saffi Eriksdotter. Heck, you can, if you want, tutor for a creature tutor, then fetch Dimir House Guard to tutor for a four-drop, thinning your deck by three and getting a creature to the grave.

If only this were a creature with flash and this ability. Then I would no doubt run it.

87965: Goblin Fire Fiend.author: GradiustheFox
87965: Goblin Fire Fiend.text_parsed:
I'm not exactly sure how many strategies would exactly be crumbled to dust by being forced to block a 1/1 monster. It's just not something I imagine you can lose a game over. I can, however, easily see someone losing a game because they blew 4 precious mana on a hilariously useless monster.
Being able to increase its attack power pretty much infinitely makes it a great glass cannon, but with the insane starting cost, and the fact that it's pretty much going to die if you sneeze on it, it's a risky investment at best.

87965: Goblin Fire Fiend.author: Ferlord
87965: Goblin Fire Fiend.text_parsed:
I can't say this is useless, especially in Limited.

The firebreathing is actually the coup de grace of this card. The real point of this isn't to be Taunting, but to force a blocker to block this. Then you boost it until you get to its toughness, and you've got 1 less pesky creature.

Obviously, it would've been nice if you could do this more than once (unless everyone's drafting 4 Birds of Paradise), but you have to take what you can get.

87965: Goblin Fire Fiend.author: Mode
87965: Goblin Fire Fiend.text_parsed:
Haste and firebreathing have a mutually exclusive use with an insultingly high cost of for a tiny 1/1.

And the third ability has the worst use imaginable on a card like that.
First of all, it's neither quite what Taunting Elf, nor what Goblin Grappler has.
Secondm you won't get anything good from this no matter what:
- Spend a ton of mana to boost him: Your opponent would gladly kill-block him with one of his wimps anyways.
- Just attack without boosting him: Fine, your opponent maybe didn't want to block it that eagerly.
But only if he only had big creatures. And unless for some reason he has nothing but utility creatures with no means to tap themselves, he'll still have the card advantage, and you're the dumb one for wasting four mana on a raging goblin.

This card would have been fine at half the cost.

87969: Conclave's Blessing.author: blurrymadness
87969: Conclave's Blessing.text_parsed:
You actually only need 3-4 tokens for make this useful:
-Convoke for 3, you're paying 1 mana for 4-6 extra toughness! BIBBITY BANG BOOM. Tokens fighting huge wurms like NUTTIN DAWG

Basically it's a mediocre card that becomes a bit ridiculous later. Best against green and/or red because even their ridiculously huge tramplers can't get through eventually. Watch out for board wipes. Probably best in bant colors so you can counter the board wipe plays and keep your unstoppable defense goin.

My original newbie deck was the typical Selesnya token deck with some convoke thrown in, WAY too much enchantment/artifact removal, and then the obligatory random cards cuz ur a nub. Still, fighting eldrazi with tokens was pretty gay/awesome.

87970: Farseek.author: achilleselbow
87970: Farseek.text_parsed:
Unfortunately the Ravnica dual lands are the only ones besides the originals that have the basic land types. So unless you're using either of those, Rampant Growth is slightly better, as it can grab forests while this can't.

Personally, I prefer Fertile Ground, as it costs the same, can produce a different color each turn, and combos well with cards that untap lands like Garruk Wildspeaker and Arbor Elf. Too bad it rotated out with Lorwyn, wish it had been reprinted.

87970: Farseek.author: endersblade
87970: Farseek.text_parsed:
A friend of mine was looking for another rampant growth effect, so I pointed this one out to him. He's running a W/U/G deck. After playing with it for the first time, he complained that it couldn't find forests, and trash-talked the card for a long time. I pointed out to him that if you're using it in a multi-colored deck, what does it matter?

I personally use Farseek ONLY to fetch dual/shock lands. Rampant growth all the way for basics. If you're running a mono-green deck, of course this card sucks compared to Rampant growth. Or if you aren't using any dual/shock lands. So he finally settled and just used two of each lol.

It IS extremely annoying that this can't fetch forests. I would've given this card a straight up 10/10 if it could.

87971: War-Torch Goblin.author: igniteice
87971: War-Torch Goblin.text_parsed:
You could attack with this against a 2/2 creature, have the opponent declare that they are blocking with the 2/2, and then sacrifice this card in response to that (before damage is dealt). You wouldn't do any further combat damage (because your creature would be in the graveyard before damage resolves), but you'd at least kill the 2/2.

Unfortunately, you could do the same with just playing Shock. However, for goblin decks, it's still a pretty decent card, and it does have great art. Ember Hauler is a much better card. Same ability cost and same damage, and it costs one more {R} to cast, but it's a 2/2 and can be sacced at any time.

87977: Blockbuster.author: Tevish_Szat
87977: Blockbuster.text_parsed: This is an excellent Rattlesnake card: it screams "Attack me and eat one-sided mass burn!"  As such, I rather feel that this card is better in a multiplayer setting than in a duel.  In a duel, your one opponent will moderate his or her attacks against you to balance doing damage with keeping things alive in case of Blockbuster.  In multiplayer, it will probably buy you a turn or two to build board position and ultimately allows you to crack it when everyone has tapped out fighting everyone else for a one-sided psuedo-wrath of god.  It's not a GREAT card, but in a free-for-all game it has the potential to be a good card.

87979: Quickchange.author: Mode
87979: Quickchange.text_parsed:
Regarding the artwork and the flavor behind it:
Consider that if you decide to give her all five colors, she'll get a sweet ghostly group hug! :D

This could have been a decent color-changing blue spell for once if the cost were only.
They are usually just underwhelming, although I'd say this one is still one of the better ones. (Prismatic Lace is probably still one of the most useful.)

And I've still seen someone running a singleton of this in a deck with Might of the Nephilim and Bloom Tender to some effectiveness. Blessing of the Nephilim should work nicely as well (e.g. on a Slippery Bogle or Geist of Saint Traft).

87981: Dimir Machinations.author: Perfect_Genetics

87981: Dimir Machinations.text_posted: Why is the rating on this so high? It is not that great for anything beyond transmute.

87981: Dimir Machinations.author: XDaragoX
87981: Dimir Machinations.text_parsed:
Perfect_Genetics: The rating is "so high" because three types of people will be looking at this card:

1) The type that needs a solid transmute card;
2) The type that really enjoys the flavor of this kind of effect;
3) People randomly lurking about Gatherer.

Let's analyze what rating each group is likely to give:
- Group 1 will see a solid transmute card at a useful CMC that can also be disruptive when absolutely necessary. I'd say, on average, they'll give this card a 3.5.
- Group 2 will see powerful library manipulation that also inspires them to get crazy with their deckbuilding ("Hey, I can finally draw that Paladin En-Vec I opened in a booster more consistently!"). They'll give this a 4 or higher.
- Group 3 is unlikely to rate the card, since it isn't particularly offensive to anyone's sensibilities (it's certainly no Jump).

That's why. Incidentally, this is a perfect example of why crowdsourcing is unreliable.

87981: Dimir Machinations.author: Hugh4893
87981: Dimir Machinations.text_parsed:
This has viable playin Legacy, specifically in Mono-Black Pox

1. It can eat up an opponents brainstorm/ponder, which in a prison deck running discard people will do after you attempt to Thoughtseize/Inquisition of kozilek/Duress/Cabal Therapy etc...

2. you can force a draw lock on the opponent, which is crutial in the pox strategy, you know they are drawing useless cards for the next few turns makes your life easier.

3. You can transmute to grab a liliana of the veil or an ensnaring bridge or any other 3 cmc you might be running.

I think it's great. The only problem with is it cost 3, but with transmute, it needs to cost 3, so it's not even that bad of a fall back. yeah, it might take you a turn to play that card you go searching for, but at least you can go get it and not be lost in a sea of uncertainty. A liliana or ensnaring bridge flat out beats decks, being able to go get one is great.

87984: Stinkweed Imp.author: blurrymadness
87984: Stinkweed Imp.text_parsed:
It's also not deathtouch because it's a triggered ability; meaning you can use something like Altar's Reap on the creature about to die in response while dealing lethal damage to Stinky.

I'm sure there are ways to abuse that as the black user, I just haven't thought of any yet..

Also, unlike deathtouch, it doesn't rely on "lethal damage", which is good and bad. Bad because a buff spell on Stinky under post-M10 rules means you have to assign lethal damage still. Good because against regeneraters that you deal lethal damage against, it'll kill them *after* they've regenerated:
-Creatures deal damage
-Stinkweed's ability goes on the stack (this happens during the combat damage step)
-State-based effects are checked, regen creature's regen kicks in and goes on top of the stack
-It regens, removes from combat etc..
-Stinkweed's ability kills it again.

Their may yet be other cool nuances that make this better/worse than deathtouch. Use and abuse it my friends.

87985: Necromantic Thirst.author: izzet_guild_mage
87985: Necromantic Thirst.text_parsed:
Noble: Combat damage is damage assigned by attacking and blocking creatures during the damage assignment step of combat (yeah, yeah, that's probably not the technical term, but you all get the gist). A "pinger" such as Prodigal Pyromancer does not ever deal combat damage with its activated ability, even if it happens to be in combat at the time (if it is, say, blocking or attacking with vigilance).
For this enchantment to work, the creature has to attack and either go unblocked or trample over. Not always easy, by no means impossible. I've seen a good deal of casual decks get good mileage out of this card.

87985: Necromantic Thirst.author: GrimjawxRULES
87985: Necromantic Thirst.text_parsed:
I don't get the low rating on this. As Themslna pointed out, putting this on an evasive creature easily nets you a lot of creatures.

People may argue that "all auras are bad ('cept those with Totem Armor) because you get 2 for 1'ed", but honestly, I've never encountered problems by running 4 or 5 auras in my decks - in fact, it has won me more than a couple of games to put an aura on a creature. So please, spare me of those 2 for 1 excuses unless all of your playmates are playing white decks with 4 Swords to Plowshares, 4 Path to Exiles, 4 Wraths, 4 Days, 4 Final Judgements, 4 Oblivion Rings and 4 Journey to Nowhere, cause frankly, I've never played against someone who packed so much removal that Auras became a bad thing to have.

So please, spare me of those 2 for 1 excuses unless all of your playmates are playing white decks with 4 Swords to Plowshares, 4 Path to Exiles, 4 Wraths, 4 Days, 4 Final Judgements, 4 Oblivion Rings and 4 Journey to Nowhere, cause frankly, I've never played against someone who packed so much removal that Auras became a bad thing to have.

87985: Necromantic Thirst.author: DacenOctavio
87985: Necromantic Thirst.text_parsed:
@Grimjaw:

Don't get me wrong, I love what this aura does when it lands on your guy and he gets in there. But dude, auras are bad. They're dead cards once you have no creatures in play. Equipment also as useless with no creatures in play, unless they're neat like Batterskull and give you a dude to wear crap. It's not so much as people think the effects auras can provide aren't worth the drawback of a well-timed Doom Blade, Lightning Bolt, Into the Roil, or Swords to Plowshares; it's that on their own, in your hand as sorcery-speed things that require a solid target, they're often clunky. Why go through all the trouble of Necromantic Thirst when you can just use a Sun Titan, who is frankly more versatile and can win games just by attacking? The name of the game is utility. The less moving parts, the more room you have for other neat things in your deck.

Now, playing with hexproof guys negates roughly half the drawback of casting an aura on your creature, but the fact that it's a card that often cannot be moved from creature to creature like a piece of equipment can can't be treated lightly.

Sword of Light and Shadow is only one mana more to play/equip in one turn, and works in any color. It also grants protection from two colors, which works as evasion a lot of the time. It also gives the creature a p/t boost.
Woebearer is a creature with this built in, and he has evasion. Also only one mana more.
I'm not likely to play this one in drafts, either. It couldn't hurt in an evasive-heavy deck, but it would rarely be great.

87990: Dimir Guildmage.author: leomistico
87990: Dimir Guildmage.text_parsed:
I like this card a little better than Azure Mage in a deck, because the discard ability. I use the discard ability until the opponent doesn't have a hand anymore, then I can cast my spells without problems. Then, I can draw cards if I need some fuel... It's much more versatile, and have a slight different use! And for the early draw, I prefer Dark Confidant than Azure Mage because I have to spend the mana for the discards...

I don't understand because some people thinks that this card is bad/overcosted. If it costed a little less, it would be not unfair but very powerful, and it deserved the rare status, at least (and compared to Cat Burglar way over the curve)... If its abilities were at instant speed, then that would be unfair: discard during the opponent's draw step, while he/she doesn't have a hand, is very brutal. For the simmetry, they had to give the same timing to the blue ability too...

4.5/5

87990: Dimir Guildmage.author: Enelysios
87990: Dimir Guildmage.text_parsed: I love this little guy. Great art first of all, but it also is nice to have repeatable draw and discard. Never underestimate how much card advantage can win games; in fact, if I could teach every new person in magic one thing, it's just HOW important card advantage is. No this isn't winning any vintage games, but I would actually consider playing this in modern. It's two great flavours that taste great together. Oh, and a two two creature! Yeah, that's nice too.

87990: Dimir Guildmage.author: sonorhC
87990: Dimir Guildmage.text_parsed: Discard abilities (especially repeatable ones like this) pretty much have to be sorcery speed, because if they're not, you could use them to lock down your opponent.  Force them to discard as soon as they draw every turn, and they'll never have a chance to cast anything but instants, nor to play any lands.

87992: Perplex.author: A0602
87992: Perplex.text_parsed:
One thing I think most people overlook is the fact that you are allowed to use this to counter a spell that you just played. Why? Choose to discard your hand. Why would I do that? That would be very situational...

If you have Brink of Madnes on the field and maybe a Megrim you can get your opponent to discard their hand.

If you have Doomed Necromancer you could use him to bring back any creature that was in your hand.

Both of these strategies are inefficient, but playable. And with the cards possibility as transmute for 3, it is pretty versatile.

"Ok, Counterspell it now."
"God damn you! >.<"

That said, it still is less reliable than those counters where they have to pay (Manaleak) as you can play around how much land they have open at the time. With this, you have no idea how good their hand is and if they want to keep it or not. It's also a completely dead card in a discard deck as when they are topdecking spells, they have no hand to discard.

Possibly combo with Telepathy effects (which help counter-based control decks anyways) but even then, you have to really know your opponent/their deck to know which option they'll choose and use it to your advantage.
87992: Perplex.text_posted:
This card can lead to some funny (for you, not your opponent) situations.

"I play [autocard]Overrun[/autocard]."
"Ok, counter it unless you discard your hand."
"Haha, I'm swinging for the win, so fine. No hand. Good game."
"Ok, [autocard]Counterspell[/autocard] it now."
"God damn you! >.<"

That said, it still is less reliable than those counters where they have to pay [X] ([autocard]Manaleak[/autocard]) as you can play around how much land they have open at the time. With this, you have no idea how good their hand is and if they want to keep it or not. It's also a completely dead card in a discard deck as when they are topdecking spells, they have no hand to discard.

Possibly combo with [autocard]Telepathy[/autocard] effects (which help counter-based control decks anyways) but even then, you have to really know your opponent/their deck to know which option they'll choose and use it to your advantage.

@OmegaSerris

Actually, Its NOT a dead card. it has transmute, so you can make it a Liliana of the Veil, for example.

you dont even need to USE it as a counter. It can just be a cmc 3 tutor.

87992: Perplex.author: Okuu-chan
87992: Perplex.text_parsed:
@pinkyandthebrain:

Yes. When your counter resolves, the Perplex's effect doesn't take place, so you're not forced to make the "Counter or discard your hand" choice.
87992: Perplex.text_posted:

Yes. When your counter resolves, the Perplex's effect doesn't take place, so you're not forced to make the "Counter or discard your hand" choice.

87995: Congregation at Dawn.author: Justice1337
87995: Congregation at Dawn.text_parsed:
Worldly Tutor x 3 at three times the cost. Quick decks with toolboxes of utility creatures will still want worldly, but where mana is less of an issue, like EDH, this one should get played. If you don't like all that glut at the top of your library, search for a Mulldrifter or an Elvish Visionary to put on the top. You really can't go wrong. I like having an enchantment or two in hand, then searching for enchantresses. Or having a dredge card in my library like Life from the Loam or Moldervine cloak, then setting up my graveyard for something like a Sun Titan recursion or a Vengeful Pharaoh, Glory, Hatred or other GY related trick. This one plays Buried Alive in the right green white deck. There really is no equal for this card.

Just don't cast this while mana starved and put something like Wood Elves on top. Did that once, won't do it again, lol.

87995: Congregation at Dawn.author: Ferlord
87995: Congregation at Dawn.text_parsed:
I always thought this was a Rare, considering how effective of a card tutor this is. Although a little colour-heavy, there are so many applications this can achieve:

Low on creatures? You won't be for a few turns!
Want to put fear in your opponents? Make them look out for Lurking Predators!
Late game and need a win condition? Pft! Who needs one creature when you can get THREE!

All in all, it's a great card perfect for EDH. Just watch out for early games and low-land hands.

87995: Congregation at Dawn.author: DarthParallax
87995: Congregation at Dawn.text_parsed:
I think you guys are critically undervaluing this card.

Then again, maybe there's just no Constructed Format to really abuse its power in besides Casual.

1) It's as sharply costed as the Mirage Tutors. To my knowledge, no other card *in. the. game* comes quite nearly as close to be a multi-tutor for the *same mana cost*. Gifts Ungiven and Buried Alive may come the closest but stipulations still require they be played not quite like Demonic Tutor would be.

2) Creatures have been *seriously* on the rise since the original Ravnica Block, and Deck Strategies have evolved somewhat too. Not many people are seriously going to be interested in what the next Burn Spell is for Red in the context of an all-spells Red Deck Wins-- Red cards are essentially either Black or White cards, depending on if they're creatures or if they kill creatures. While non-Gold decks are not a thing of the past, at the same time Mono-Color Decks today have to do about as many things as Gold Decks did in Invasion to get anywhere. Mythic Rarity allows some Creatures to be almost equal to or even better than some Planeswallkers. Artifact-Equipment cards turned out to be much more influential on the game also than was quite guessed by the time this card made it to print.
Sure, they were a known quantity, but like Creatures, Artifact-Equipment deal more with the Battlefield than the Stack, and the game is now about the Battlefield more than anything else (in much part it's due to that being the only way to prevent Planeswalker Decks from running absolute havoc.) Mid-Range decks of every Color of the Rainbow abound in Standard every year, with heavy reliance on the 'spells' tacked onto already-fat-bodies.

The point is, "Creature" is a far better card type to search for than Instant or Sorcery nowadays anyway, unless it's a really mana-heavy Instant or Sorcery, something that Board Wipes or does something like Cryptic Command or Sphinx's Revelation.

3) I DON'T think we'll be seeing this card in Standard again, but it's possible we *may* see it on a Planeswalker.

4) GW/x decks should almost always play 4, Creature Decks should almost always splash for at least 2.5 (2 main 1 side), and Combo decks should consider playing it in wacked decks that do stuff like Emrakul the Aeons Torn.

This effect will never be 3 mana again.


4.8/5 Stars.

88951: Undercity Shade.author: Leshrac_Nightwalker
88951: Undercity Shade.text_parsed:
It's a lot to shell out for a 1/1 - I do realize that evasion and :+1/+1 ueot can't really be cheaper (at least not at uncommon), but it seems like it'll draw removal almost as soon as you play it, and without reserve on the turn you cast him, he is pretty fragile.

It just OOZES with flavour, though, and as usual I really like it for that. The Boros guild are badasses (I would think twice about crossing a police force whose rank-and-file are called "torchers"!), and they've got an "official story" to explain away their fear of the thing. The urban setting was a very interesting take on the game's lore, and I can almost see Agrus Kos taking a drag, gritty-cop-style, in the middle of that text. It's just so perfect. :)

88951: Undercity Shade.author: blurrymadness
88951: Undercity Shade.text_parsed:
4 would make him on par with the other OK shades
3 would make him quite good and debatable over Nantuko Shade

Something I like about shades when they *don't* have evasion, however, is that they can be used to generate card advantage. You bluff your opponent enough times and he can be sure whether you'll sink in the mana to save him or whether he's taking 6 that he could've blocked. If they don't block you can just play a spell and then pump however much is left over. This allows you to maintain tempo, have a nigh-unblockable creature, or be generating a lot of card advantage by a wary opponent.

88952: Light of Sanction.author: Mode
88952: Light of Sanction.text_parsed:
A narrow and not too powerful effect that won't do anything by itself.
I'd have prefered this as a creature or if it would have been cheaper. Would surely make an interesting one-drop.
It's one of those cards that might get interesting with the print of a certain card in a future set though.
But still, for three mana i would have prefered it to protect me as well.

Right now there are already plenty of red and various black cards that combine with this card though:
Pyroclasm/Volcanic Fallout, Flamebreak, Slagstorm, Chain Reaction, Kindle the Carnage, Martyr of Ashes, this card's expansion buddy Hammerfist Giant, Ryusei, the Falling Star
If you want more enchantments, try Pyrohemia or the black original classic, Pestilence.

And this also works with masochistic creatures of course like Psionic Sliver. Wave of Reckoning might be a nice alternative to the red burn spells if you don't want to run red (which i generally wouldn't quite call a good idea).

88956: Necroplasm.author: Kiro
88956: Necroplasm.text_parsed:
"achilleselbow, does 'protection from black' mean nothing to you?"

Protection from Black doesn't protect from global sweeping. Achilleselbow's combo works.

Protection means:

Can't be blocked by creatures of that color/type
Can't be targeted by spells or abilities of that color/type
Prevent all damage from all sources of that color/type
Can't be enchanted or equipped by cards of that color/type

Necroplasm does neither of those things so it can totally blow up stuff with protection from black.

A Black Knight did, does and always will die to Wrath of God. At the same time, a Silver Knight will survive a red sweeper like Earthquake because that's damage and not destroy.

88960: Golgari Grave-Troll.author: Mike-C
88960: Golgari Grave-Troll.text_parsed: The very recent Splinterfright from Innistrad is resemblent of this guy. I think I like Splinter even better despite his lack of abilities when compared to this guy b/c of his casting cost and even more than that, his ability to fill a graveyard, FAST. That has magnificent synergy with so many of the cards from most of the latest expansions. The dredge on this guy and regen is awesome and counters are almost always fun, but for me personally, I'd pick Splinterfright over him and when it's all said and done, I think most would agree on that. It's still early but I think he's going to be just BRUTAL.

88962: Zephyr Spirit.author: Mode
88962: Zephyr Spirit.text_parsed:
Blue epic fail Wall of Junk.
Yes, it can attack and it doesn't take any damage either as opposed to other cards of that sort (Phantom Whelp, Quicksilver Behemoth, Windscouter and the aforementioned wall).
But why would you want wasting 6 freaking mana each time to get an attacking creature blocked? You could simply use any ability to tap the accordant creature instead (for example by using Puppeteer), which will keep it from attacking and triggering accordant abilities as well.
And returning the Spirit isn't even optional (although even if it was, this card would still be terrible for 6 mana).

I don't exactly know what Wizards thought when making this card, but apparently they were in Chimney Imp common slot trolling mood again.
88962: Zephyr Spirit.text_posted:

But why would you want wasting 6 freaking mana each time to get an attacking creature blocked? You could simply use any ability to tap the accordant creature instead (for example by using [autocard]Puppeteer[/autocard]), which will keep it from attacking and triggering accordant abilities as well.

88962: Zephyr Spirit.author: Gaussgoat
88962: Zephyr Spirit.text_parsed:
At first glance, this thing seems utterably miserable... but that's not entirely true. The card itself is very good, it is really only the Mana Cost that kills you.

You basically get a card that can block virtually any creature and resists quite a bit of direct damage with a 6 toughness. If you get creative in getting it on the table, you have some major-league defense the can stop virtually anything, with the lone exception of trample.

Elvish Piper and this guy gives you a blocker every turn that is effectively indestructable, barring massive direct damage.

Wacky, but usable. 2/5

88962: Zephyr Spirit.author: nimzo
88962: Zephyr Spirit.text_parsed:
You are missing something: Bounteous Kirin: Legendary Creature — Kirin Spirit (4/4) Flying. "Whenever you cast a Spirit or Arcane spell, you may gain life equal to that spell's converted mana cost". Cloudhoof Kirin: Legendary Creature — Kirin Spirit (4/4) Flying. "Whenever you cast a Spirit or Arcane spell, you may put the top X cards of target player's library into his or her graveyard, where X is that spell's converted mana cost".

I can mention so many card in the Kamigawa block with this kind of trick, 51 contain the words "when", "cast", "spirit" and "spell"... (Sire of the Storm, Skyfire Kirin, Thief of Hope)... or other, like Primordial Sage. So Zephyr Spirit deserve a very honorable 1,5/5, nearly 2/5 for the creative Jonny player we are, because it gives you the possibility to cast it each turn and to block a big non flying creature...

88963: Mnemonic Nexus.author: sarroth
88963: Mnemonic Nexus.text_parsed:
dberry02: "Only use this spell if you need instant speed graveyard shuffle. Otherwise, most of the time it's better to use Reminisce."

Not exactly. Reminisce doesn't stop your opponents from abusing their graveyards. Sure, this is no Relic of Progenitus for taking care of the graveyard threat, but this delays the graveyard play while also giving you access to a ton of cards you might not have had if you weren't running recursion yourself. As with a lot of cards, this only gets better as you design your deck to fit with it. The more recursion your opponents have, the more dead cards they have for a while just because you cast this. While you're drawing a ton of cards off of, say, Consecrated Sphinx and not decking yourself because you cast this.

88965: Brainspoil.author: Kelrath
88965: Brainspoil.text_parsed:
Transmute is the most underrated ability ever. Does no one realize that Transmute allows you to place combos in your hand?

Example: Brainspoil and Dizzy Spell are in your hand. Stuffy Doll and Guilty Conscience are in your deck.

This card deserves a much higher rating, if not simply for being a transmute card, then for being the only one with 5 CMC.

88965: Brainspoil.author: nimzo
88965: Brainspoil.text_parsed:
@ Kelrath, @Kindulas
The problem is about the fact that you'll probably not running with many 5CMC in your deck. So by the time you will transmute it, you'll find between 1-2 and 4-5 card in your deck as a target, and maybe you'll not ready to play the tutored card next turn. I understand the Stuffy Doll - Guilty Conscience combo where Brainspoil can be useful, but how many card can kill this combo? Boomrang, Counterspell, Disenchant are three common and classic example, both between 4 and 5 stars, card with so many possibilities. Stuffy Doll and Guilty Conscience are both interesting and strong card, but if you need two other cards and (with Dizzy Spell) at your turn to then reach your combo, maybe the way is a little bit hazardous...

Furthermore, how many time the first card at the top of your library is the desirable card? This make Fleeting Distraction a 3,5 or 4 stars card?

So because the "main" effect (at sorcery speed) of Brainspoil doesn't deserve more than 2CMC (kill black, but non-enchanted creature), and because the restrictive of both his casting cost and his trasmute ability, this card is definitively a 2,5/5 stars card and the lower of the "transmute card" of the multicolored world of Ravnica (compare it with Dimir Infiltrator, where the "main" card exactly deserves his 2CMC as a strong card, so the trasmute ability is in this case a veritable bonus).

I agree on one point: Transmute is very interesting for imaginative player and for non-standard way of making things. And don't forget: 2,5/5 or 3/5 are "decent" or "good" card, it's not so pejorative!

88965: Brainspoil.author: leomistico
88965: Brainspoil.text_parsed:
In limited it's quite playable even if there isn't anything worth the transumation in you deck. In constructed it's a versatile tutor that can kill something when you're in need! It's nothing to laugh of because that means that your removal isn't a dead card even if there's nothing to kill. Of course you have to build your deck a little according to it, but it's no so difficult. Compare it to Expunge that's already a very good card!

@nimzo: The difference between draw a card and tutor for a desired card is so huge that if you don't understand it you may have some problem playing Magic... So comparing this with tutor effect with the "Draw a card" one of Fleeting Distraction doesn't make any sense.

Even if there's only one 5CMC remaining in your deck, if you need it, you'll be happy to draw Brainspoil. Even if you don't exactly NEED it, it's worth the transmutation if Brainspoil is a dead card at that moment.
I agree that it's cost doesn't match the effect like, as you said, Dimir Infiltrator, but it's not bad compared to Ethereal Usher. And sometime all you need is a 5CMC flexible tutor...!

4/5

88965: Brainspoil.author: ElliotSternberg
88965: Brainspoil.text_parsed:
There should be a separate rating system for EDH, because this card is amazing in it. I've used this to kill mean things with regenerate, other creatures that would have murdered my face off, pull exquisite blood to match my sanguine bond and grab other combos very often.

Not to mention that with the new set Diabolic Revelation can be grabbed and then fetch you a whole combo if you've done good mana ramp. (At times I can play this, then revalations and then drop Mikaeus and Triskelion in a single turn.)

I would guess it's too high cost for modern and vintage, but EDH has a great time with this.

Ugh, I hate how the Oracle doesn't cover some situations that just need clearly stated for some people (like me). Such as this: How does Trample interact with it? Will it just absorb the equivalent of it it's stats and then the rest of the Trample moves on, or does it just absorb the whole thing?

Hmmm, and I guess it doesn't count as "prevent damage" since it doesn't say prevent, huh?
88969: Phytohydra.text_posted:
Ugh, I hate how the Oracle doesn't cover some situations that just need clearly stated for some people (like me). Such as this: How does Trample interact with it? Will it just absorb the equivalent of it it's stats and then the rest of the Trample moves on, or does it just absorb the whole thing?

Hmmm, and I guess it doesn't count as "prevent damage" since it doesn't say prevent, huh?

88969: Phytohydra.author: SpencerDub
88969: Phytohydra.text_parsed:
@JarieSuicune: The controller of the attacking creature need only apply "lethal" damage to the Phytohydra before assigning its trample damage to the defending player. If the Phytohydra had no +1/+1 counters on it, then only one point of damage would need to be assigned.

The damage would then turn into a +1/+1 counter, but at that point, the damage would have already been assigned, so the Phytohydra wouldn't suddenly block more damage. Additionally, unless the trample damage was done with first (or double) strike, the counter would be placed after the assign damage step, so Phytohydra would also only hit back for 1.

Of course, since it's technically the attacking player's choice, he or she could theoretically assign more than lethal damage to the Phytohydra. This would only cause it to grow more, and would reduce the amount of trample damage dealt to the defending player.

88969: Phytohydra.author: ClockworkSwordfish
88969: Phytohydra.text_parsed:
This card is one of my favourites. It dies to Doom Blade, sure, but you have so much more fun than the guy playing DB that that doesn't matter a bit. It's best if you can flash it into play (not the battlefield, gorramit) when your opponent attacks with a fattie and then watch the look on your his face change from mild disappointment about the new chump blocker to dismay and then fear, at just about the time he reads the word "instead". Barrels of monkeys have nothing on this. I played Guided Strike on my opponent's creature after he announced blockers. Crowned by the amazing art, it just doesn't get better than this, folks. It has its flaws, but cards like this make the game worth playing. 5/5, no question.

Edit: Forgot to mention that this + Pariah + Druid's Call = the most fun combo in the game.

2nd edit: Sorry. That doesn't work. Still, Pariah...

88969: Phytohydra.author: HeartbreakerStudios
88969: Phytohydra.text_parsed:
Those are Outrider en-Kors trying to drag it down with Spidersilk Nets and feed it Inquisitor's Flails for breakfast. They make sure it grows up big and strong.

The wise Phytohydra knows to pack a Lure and Rancor when it goes into battle, and to call on Ghave, Guru of Spores to give it a makeover when it becomes regularly chump blocked.

There's also Rite of Consumption. Mean, yes, but game-winning.

And yes, it's spelled out right on the card, guys. It takes +1/+1 counters INSTEAD of damage. That means it's IMMUNE to Deathtouch (which only activates when a creature takes damage), Wither, and Infect (which are stated as "damage in the form of -1/-1 counters").

88972: Netherborn Phalanx.author: Angerr
88972: Netherborn Phalanx.text_parsed: This was one of my favourite cards in Ravnica block limited. It can steal otherwise lost games from your opponent in a way even most experienced players won't usually suspect. The effect is just too unique. I remember winning with it a seemingly lost game against a growing army of flyers off a Leafdrake Roost and praying for the last creature needed to come out for my opponent so I can finish him with this card. What's more, you can "tutor" with it another 6 mana bomb from your deck ( playing more 6 mana cards in a limited deck isn't always a great idea though) - Hex, for example, is in the same format. Really an excellent card, only sometimes a bit unfair.

88973: Twilight Drover.author: Yendorian
88973: Twilight Drover.text_parsed:
Obviously benefits from Doubling Season in myriad ways.

There are also a number of token generators with non-permanent tokens that play well with this card. Minion Reflector, Kiki Jiki, Mirror Breaker, Zektar Shrine Expedition, Nacatl War-Pride, etc. Slap an Elemental Mastery on him and he becomes ridiculous in very short order.

I also saw this card get amusingly huge in a Bant-colored deck featuring things like Hunted Phantasm, Phelddagrif and Forbidden Orchard, plus Leyline of Singularity. When the leyline got removed, the player proceeded to bring out the fliers.

88973: Twilight Drover.author: TAGVoar
88973: Twilight Drover.text_parsed:
The best part about this guy is it only cares about +1/+1 counters, so anything that puts a +1/+1 on it will do the trick, but if you are just going for making this guy massive, then use Heartless Summoning and improve it with Training Grounds
Throw him and Grimgrin, Corpse Born into the graveyard and have a Necrotic Ooze on the battlefield works pretty nicely too.
Use Scapegoat (probably on the Isochron Scepter) along with something ridiculously broken like Endless Ranks of the Dead. If you have have a few of those out, you'll get something in the area of 70 tokens every few turns, and they all bounce, thus leave the battlefield.

88973: Twilight Drover.author: Lord_of_Tresserhorn
88973: Twilight Drover.text_parsed:
This.
One Ashnod's Altar.
One Farrelite Priest. (Or Skyshroud Elf for reuseability, but also adds green.)
One Training Grounds.

And a single token from somewhere.

1. Sacrifice a token with Ashnod's Altar to add {2} to your mana pool and put a +1/+1 counter on Twilight Drover.
2. Use Farrelite Priest to turn {2} into {W}{W}.
3. Use {W} (as the activation cost has been reduced by Training Grounds) and remove the counter to activate Twilight Drovers ability, putting two Spirit tokens into play.
4. GOTO 1.

Voila, infinite {W} and infinite Spirits.

88973: Twilight Drover.author: Lash_of_Dragonbreath
88973: Twilight Drover.text_parsed:
@TAGVoar: Heartless Summoning would kill Twilight Drover and most of your tokens, so I wouldn't reccomend using it. Necrotic Ooze, with both this and Grimgrin, Corpse-born in your graveyard wouldn't be much more amusing than either a Jade Mage or a Sphinx of Magosi, unless I'm missing something. And, from all the cards you mentioned, Endless Ranks of the Dead is actually the less broken one. Seriously, Isochron Scepter and Training Grounds? You might as well throw in a Doubling Season and a Skullclamp. These cards are so combo-able that it's kinda pointless to even mention them.

So, this card. It's definetly a fun one in a token deck. You could either use it to multiply your tokens or just let the +1/+1 counters pile up and turn this into a beatstick (and maybe while still leaving some mana open to make some spirits in case someone points some removal at him). Not to mention all the possible combos with him (just look at most creatures in Ghave, guru of spores' precon commander deck).
Also, with Innistrad and Dark Ascension bringing us a lot of new spirit token makers (Midnight Haunting and Mausoleum Guard, for example), this could be a bombastic (not sure if that word exists) addition to a white token deck, at least in casual.

88979: Ursapine.author: DoctorKenneth
88979: Ursapine.text_parsed:
Shades in black are a win condition. You catch your foe when he or she has let their guard down, and swing for the win. The shade lurks on the edges of combat, easily pinging away life due to the constant threat of it becoming suddenly bigger than the creatures blocking it. But the shade ability in green? The colour of mana acceleration? It gets so much bigger, and so much scarier.

You have this (a 3/3), an elephant (3/3), and two 2/2s. It's the turn after you play this. You have six mana open. You swing at your opponent with everything. They have two 4/4s and a 1/1. What do they block? Nothing? 16 damage, potentially. Or 10 and you drop a blocker postcombat. Do they block something? They will lose a creature. You probably won't. This puts some serious pressure on your opponents, and can force them into making some sub-par choices.

Accelerate some mana, and you won't lose a creature to damage any time soon.

88981: Belltower Sphinx.author: DocBernard
88981: Belltower Sphinx.text_parsed:
I see a few comments here about it being useless or overpriced for what you are getting. That's just wrong. This card has basically made my standard mono-blue mill deck unstoppable among my friends (to the point that some friends even refuse to play against it).

Simply put, if you have four in your deck, by turn five (or four if you have some sort of mana ramping) you are putting down a 2/5 blocker that brutally punishes the opponent for trying to hit you. At one point, I had a friend beef up a creature to throw down 13 damage in one turn. I simply sacrificed the Belltower Sphinx and immediately the next turn played another Belltower Sphinx.

As for removal over actually killing it, that's why ever blue deck should run some Cancels/Negates/Essence Scatter/Mana Leak cards that prevent that sort of problem. Even better, is keeping 1 mana open for an unsummon. Now unsummons can be used for the first three or four turns to keep the battlefield shuffling well you set up a few Jace's Erasures and get your first Belltower Sphinx out. Then, the unsummons serve as very useful cards. Your opponent attacks with two large creatures, forcing you to only be able to block one? Unsummon the other and use your Sphinx to punish them. Even better, when the player goes to use Plummet or Pacificsm or whatever they have in reserve to stop the Sphinx, simply unsummon him and play him again immediately next turn.

Really, this card is clearly a vital card to any mill deck, along side such wonders as Jace's Erasure or Merfolk Mesmerist.

88982: Mindmoil.author: kiseki
88982: Mindmoil.text_parsed:
This can't just go into any deck. It means you always have cards you can play, but your hand approaches zero cards quickly in the general case. And then this is useless. Also, your hand of good cards becomes a hand of ~40% mana sources. If you want to get good mileage out of this, you have to be able to resist playing the lands.
It is a good combo piece, and cantrips work well, but it doesn't take many playtests to realize that you need to build around it.
If you had two out, the ability would go on the stack twice, and you could play instants from the first draw before you shuffle the cards in again.

88982: Mindmoil.author: Justice1337
88982: Mindmoil.text_parsed:
Yes, this card is very, very good in EDH even outside of combo, especially in mono-red. You can use it in so many ways.

You could use it to get as much land in play as you want, from something like an Explore, because you put on bottom a hand of mostly non-land and grab a hand with a random sample of land. Then, you play whatever draw spell your deck gave you, if any, and look at a new hand. You can also cycle through your deck looking for all your Rav Bounce lands, playing tons of land and generating card advantage. This comes in particularly handy if you want to play a deck with a lot of mass Land Destruction. You blow up all the lands, this activates, then your new hand will likely have a land or two in it, then maybe one spell that you can play with that amount of mana. You play that, get a new hand, repeat. It's like your deck can't possibly give you the high CMC cards that you can't play anymore, and you are lucking into a low CMC hand where everyone else is looking at the same cards they can't cast for the rest of the game.

You can use it to grab whatever card you need out of your deck, of course. Diabolic Tutor is cheaper, but this thing lasts for the whole game. It gets really sick decks that are designed to bounce things to your hand, etc. Even something like a Sensei's Diving Top bounces to your hand next turn, you replay it, get a new hand until you find the card you need. Crystal Shard shennanigans become really sick. And don't even get me started with Shrieking Drake. For that matter, this is going to be pretty sick in any Animar deck. Find Shrieking Drake, Tunnel Ignus, etc, then something like Erayo, Soratami Ascendant.

Just the card you want to see in EDH, and it's red.

88982: Mindmoil.text_parsed:
Damn interesting card, and fits best in an Izzet shell. Psychosis Crawler and Niv-Mizzet, The Firemind are made deadly.

With this in mind, you can set off tons of draw effects with rebound cards like Staggershock, or just use Whirlpool Warrior to deal tons of damage with the Crawler or Niv-Mizzet.

Card advantage cards are preferable; Firemind's Foresight or Reforge The Soul can get you Mindmoiling much more effectively after they've resolved. You'll also want cheap cards to set it off, like Gitaxian Probe or Gut Shot.

88984: Seed Spark.author: nemokara
88984: Seed Spark.text_parsed:
Turning it around, the Izzet guild could be criticized for being so focused on innovation that they lose some of the focus and drive that comes from having everyone working in unison towards a common goal. Sure, their experimentation will sometimes result in some new and interesting synergies, but they miss out on a different kind of synergy: the kind that arises from having every piece fitting together as one harmonious whole.

Flavor aside, this is a rather mediocre Naturalize variant. Nowadays it would probably be one mana cheaper, and even then would still be about average in power level. In a GW token deck, I'd probably prefer using Sundering Vitae, Aura Shards, and/or Gleeful Sabotage instead.

88984: Seed Spark.author: blurrymadness
88984: Seed Spark.text_parsed:
All the colors are logical. Do they all act in a way we agree with? No, that's why people prefer colors that fit their mood or their mindset; their logic. When black makes a sacrifice for power the logic is that the sacrifice is worth the power; whether he turns out to be correct or incorrect it was logic that guided him.

When the white mage obliterates everything he assumes (logically) that if everything is dead and gone there will finally be peace again. The Red mage, chaotic as he is, loves destruction and logically decides that red magic suits his needs (as he blows up lands, artifacts and sets the world afire.) He needs not act in a way YOU deem logical or correct; he's chosen the mana for which will suit him; which requires logic. It requires thought.

Even the red mage who sows chaos (while he could well be crazy) is doing so because he enjoys it; there's no reason to assume that non-determinism => alogical.


At any rate, still a sideboard card unless you keep extra enchants handy (such as fists of ironwood) to get the extra couple saps in a bad situation. 2-3 of in Multiplayer decks should be fine though :D

88986: Vigor Mortis.author: achilleselbow
88986: Vigor Mortis.text_parsed:
Hmm, good point MortySan. I looked it up: literally it says: "return target creature card from graveyard to play." Russian not only lacks definite and indefinite articles ('a' and 'the') but often omits other modifiers and adjectives as well, with the meaning derivable from context. I think the 'your' is implied in that sentence, but obviously it should be worded more clearly.

On another note, I'd hate to be the guy whose job it is to translate cards into Russian. Well not really, obviously I'd love to work for Wizards, but the rules and effects are so awkwardly worded and so much of the flavor is lost. I wonder if seems as weird to non-English-speaking Russian players. This card is a perfect example - there is simply no way to translate the pun, so the Russian name reads something like "Rotten Hardening". Ugh. I wish they were a little less literal with the translations and at least tried to make the cards sound cool in the target language.

I think the 'your' is implied in that sentence, but obviously it should be worded more clearly.

On another note, I'd hate to be the guy whose job it is to translate cards into Russian. Well not really, obviously I'd love to work for Wizards, but the rules and effects are so awkwardly worded and so much of the flavor is lost. I wonder if seems as weird to non-English-speaking Russian players. This card is a perfect example - there is simply no way to translate the pun, so the Russian name reads something like "Rotten Hardening". Ugh. I wish they were a little less literal with the translations and at least tried to make the cards sound cool in the target language.

88986: Vigor Mortis.author: BegleOne
88986: Vigor Mortis.text_parsed:
If a deck is able to reanimate any beastie from the graveyard, then giving that beastie +1/+1 shouldn't be that big of a boon. Still, in a green-splashing deck it's usually better than Zombify, in a deck without many creatures it's better than Dread Return, in a deck without self-milling it's better than Stitch Together, in an exceedingly rare situation where you're playing a deck with bigger critters than you it's better than Exhume, and better than Soul Exchange if you have no little thrull-ish creatures running around.

Still usually option fourth or fifth at best if you're putting together a deck in an eternal or casual format.

88990: Helldozer.author: achilleselbow
88990: Helldozer.text_parsed: My friend and I used to play Ravnica block a lot and I had this guy in my Golgari deck for a while. Eventually I ended up taking him out because he just didn't work that well. I think the biggest reason was the lack of trample, as Ravnica had a lot of options for tokens and chump blockers. Like someone said, destroying a land on turn 6 or 7 isn't going to kill your opponent. And you'll usually want to attack with him every turn, which means you'll only use his ability on nonbasics, which your opponent will have maybe 2 of max unless you're playing a prismatic deck or something. Nonbasics help a lot with color balance in the early game, but by the time you get this guy out your opponent should have the basics they need to not get color-screwed. All in all, I've never encountered a situation where I wouldn't rather have a Gleancrawler out, and that has a less restrictive mana cost with an awesome static ability.

You're supposing to do this in turn 9 or with 9 lands, that isn't absolutely true. First, because it doesn't have haste. Second because it's not an enchantment that doesn't do anything else other that destroy lands for . You actually are paying for a 6/5 creature! Then next turn you can pay for destroy a land and, if it was a nonbasic, you untap it and destroy another land or attack. I don't see something like "9 mana and two turns to destroy a land", but actually much more! Then you said: Killing a land each turn will be annoying but not game changing then.... After turn 6 nobody plays a land each turn, but maybe once in 2/3 turns, so destroy a land each turn IS game changing! In 4 turns (10th turn) I have something like 8 lands, you something like 4, if you're lucky (aka don't play nonbasic)! I know that everthing I said is hypothetical, but are options that you didn't consider...
Sorry for being so rude... I usually like your comments, but this time not so much!

88991: Voyager Staff.author: Lash_of_Dragonbreath
88991: Voyager Staff.text_parsed:
I run this card in EDH. This is very good in a blink deck, especially one with Sharuum, the Hegemon as its general.
3 total mana to blink one creature isn't too much, at least in EDH and when you're blinking something like Sphinx of Uthuun, Sphinx Summoner or Filigree Angel.
Then, it's also an artifact, which interacts very well with a lot of things. For example, it makes Sharuum very hard to kill, and counts as one more thing to recur with Open the Vaults.
It's not golden by any means, but it deserves more than a 2.3 rating. 3.5 sounds fairer.

88992: Boros Recruit.author: Asmodi0000
88992: Boros Recruit.text_parsed:
Possibly my favorite one drop in the game. He's not the most powerful, but that's part of his charm. No one ever wants to waste a spell to kill him, which gives him a chance to prove himself. While there's the superior Figure of Destiny who shares the same casting cost, he's still an excellent card with a surprising number of far larger creatures that he triumphs against in a fight, especially in the early turns of the game where a toughness of 1 isn't that uncommon.

He can find his place into a lot of decks. Goblins, soldiers, any place a reliable 1/1 first striker for 1 can slip in. While Figure is the golden boy of the R/W crew, boros recruit is at least a fair bit better than duergar assailant.

88992: Boros Recruit.author: DarthParallax
88992: Boros Recruit.text_parsed:
This is a goblin. In uniform. Helping other races. Just got me thinking.....
Anyone here play the Epic War series on Kongregate?

Kaalia of the Vast's Epic War Deck (non-EDH):
Tinker + Mox Lotus = Yay Mana! :)

Doubling Season + Alliance of Arms = HOBBIT SPAM
+ Mercy Killing = ELF SPAM
+ Rise of the Hobgoblins = GOBLIN SPAM (and all your creatures get First Strike-they're all Boros Recruits!) *the rest of this post has nothing to do with Boros Recruit. It's just an excercise in sillyness. Epic War fans should appreciate it, though.*

Mirror-Sigil Sergeant + Followed Footsteps = PALADIN SPAM
Precursor Golem + Rite of Replication= GOLEM SPAM (o.O)
Mirror Hall + Riku of Two Reflections= WIZARD SPAM/SPAM SPAM (okay this is seriously getting ridiculous, but lolz this is fun! xD)
Academy Rectors + Day of the Dragons= BLUE DRAGON SPAM (I'm surprised that Magic has a way to generate lots of Blue Dragons. Rules text says Red, but the artist says blue :)
Mirror Hall + Rakdos the Defiler + Splinter Twin as BALROG SPAM (sacrifing about 3 infinities worth of Doubled Dragon Tokens you got from exiling 1 infinity worth of Golems and another infinity of Paladins)
Decree of Justice + Luminarch Ascension + Baneslayer Angel + Necrotic Ooze + Experiment Kraj+ The Mimeoplasm + Essence of the Wild= Creatures enter the battlefield as a copy of Baneslayer Angel. I think. And ANGEL SPAM. Somewhere in there you're going to have a lot of tokens coming back because of leaving the battlefield/enters the battlefield triggers and causing some mental train wrecks cuz I think some of them blink from Day of Dragons. Even without that you can probably get a way with declaring you have an arbitrarily large number of everything.
Warsturm Surge + Comet Storm as the SPECIAL ATTACKS (don't forget to use Riku on the Comets)
Sun Titan + Grave Titan + Inferno Titan as Themselves

The last thing it needed was an Archenemy to fight.

Worldgorger Dragon + Novablast Wurm + Progenitus + Polymerization (not even a Magic card, I know)= The End.


LoL, I wonder which side has the advantage? xxXDD

Not bad for a 1/1 Goblin. :P
http://www.kongregate.com/games/rudy_sudarto/epic-war

88992: Boros Recruit.author: MagicBrad
88992: Boros Recruit.text_parsed:
It'd be tough to rate this one poorly unless you held some form of prejudice.
- A 1/1 for 1 is a pretty standard deal. This is easier to cast than most because you can use or , so in a standard two-color deck it comes out with either of your basic lands.
- First strike is a great combat ability, and fairly uncommon among one-drops.
- It's a Goblin, and there are a ton of great red Goblins for a tribal deck.
- It's a Soldier, and there are a ton of great Soldiers for a tribal deck in white, and red to a lesser extent.

Now, I'm not particularly thrilled about the art or the flavour text, and a Goblin fighting for an orderly organization seems a little off to me, but from a point of view looking strictly at playability, this card is an example of an excellent generalist first-turn creature.

88997: Instill Furor.author: BrutalJim
88997: Instill Furor.text_parsed: It's rated so low because it's definitely no red Doom Blade. It's sorcery speed, it's a aura, (meaning if your opponent has enchantment destruction they can save their creature) and lastly it doesn't help you at all if you try to play it on a creature that your opponent is already smacking you with in the first place. It's only real use is playing it on a wall or a creature that your opponent is just using for the ability, and in which case Lightning Bolt can usually do the job.

88997: Instill Furor.author: Mode
88997: Instill Furor.text_parsed:
An effect with such a highly conditional use should either be a cantrip or at least cost only.

Bloodshed Fever is almost strictly better:

This effect is usually even worse than just making the creature attack no matter what, since your opponent gets the choice to use the enchanted creature for something else one last turn instead.

The only exception to this is if you enchant a creature that can't attack, like creatures with defender.

88998: Convolute.author: leomistico
88998: Convolute.text_parsed:
The original Ravnica block did a ton of good things, but it didn't have a mono-color hard counter! Not only one!

Convolute: not hard counter
Frazzle: target limitation, and overcosted
Induce Paranoia: needs black to do something that justify the high mana cost
Muddle the Mixture: limited to instant/sorcery
Remand: really good to gain tempo, but not exactly an hard counter
Runeboggle: not an hard counter
Spell Snare: target limitation

I would have really liked to see something like Hinder, Dissipate, Dismal Failure, Dismiss, hell, even Cancel! Moreover, the only guild that didn't get an hard counter is Izzet... It only gets Odds! This fact still bothers me...!

This one is a variant of Mana Leak that can surprise an opponent prepared to pay , but not . It's not a bad card, but not good enough...
2.5/5

89001: Life from the Loam.author: cats_and_me
89001: Life from the Loam.text_parsed:
This card is part of one of the most interesting and effective card-draw engines! :) Together with cycle lands like Tranquil Thicket, you can draw three cards for five mana as many times as you like, but you have to spend the first two mana at the same time and during the main phase.. Also, you can trigger powerful cards like Lightning Rift or Astral Slide over and over! :)

Edit: True, you have to skip one draw to get this card back into your hand, but you choose between skipping one of your draw steps and skipping one of the draws when cycling a land card.. Thank you for your correction! :)

89001: Life from the Loam.author: Rezzy64
89001: Life from the Loam.text_parsed:
Every time I hear people talk about this card I get sad.
Back when Ravnica first came out I was still in my early Timmy stages, I didn't fully grasp the concept of card advantage and I thought Dredge was terrible. Yes I was a hardcore noob during Ravnica. I opened this card in a booster at my local card shop and a loud resounding "What the hell is this good for?" was heard from my mouth. Many advanced players came over to me and gasped. One very sneaky player came over very quickly and smiled. "I'll trade you a Grozoth for that."
I made that trade so fast that my Timmy spirit was on fire. I thought I had taken that guy for a sucker.
Now... I look back on that day, and simply shake my head, if only I had known.

89002: Vindictive Mob.author: Radagast
89002: Vindictive Mob.text_parsed:
I had to do a double take when I first saw one of these lying around... Let's see... A 5/5 for 4BB. Okay, it had better be useful. Sac a creature when it comes into play... Oh, boy... this thing had better have some amazing abilities! Can't be blocked by Saprolings... HUH?!?!?! Shouldn't it have Fear or something to justify the name and the absurd cost?!

I have no idea what they were on when they made this card? A 5/5 for 4BB that can't be blocked by Saprolings is basically a Craw Wurm - why does it need to sac a creature, too? And who cares about Saprolings? And isn't a 5/5 large enough to handle Saprolings that are almost always 1/1's? And how does this card make any sense at all? Plants fleeing the angry mob? A mob that wants to hunt down plants? Huh?!

89002: Vindictive Mob.author: Vogie
89002: Vindictive Mob.text_parsed:
This card is a really interesting one if you look at it with a Vorthosian perspective. The planeswalker needs to create a Mob... so they kill someone. They point the blame to some Druids, the Selesnya or the Golgari (or any saproling-using group). They're vindicitive, they're vengeful, they're not going to be deterred by the cheap chumps plants.

... Little do they know, they're just not attacking the right people.

This card is very, very black, and makes a whole lot more sense once you get over the fact that you'll probably never use it outside of sealed/draft

89002: Vindictive Mob.author: DarthParallax
89002: Vindictive Mob.text_parsed:
http://wizards.com/Magic/Magazine/Article.aspx?x=mtg/daily/mm/251

It's "Trinket Text". Normally, I'd say Trinket Text shouldn't cost mana. Here's the catch though:

This is a Black Card that is a sacrifice outlet. As unintuitive as it is at first, we have come a long way with this little game of ours, and it is CORRECT that sacrifice outlets should be charged a mana-premium. :P should this be both uncommon And 6 mana? ...na, I'd be ok with uncommon and 5 mana, or common and 6 mana.

it could have Trample.

this card is either underdeveloped or overdeveloped, but if you add the line 'When Craw Wurm ETB, sac a creature" to a Craw Wurm, then Paint it Black, you have made a Better Craw Wurm. Not Strictly Better, but better.

Green can pretend that sacrificing a creature to play a creature is a downside. Black cannot. That's my opinion.

It's a 5/5 because it represents 5 1/1 human tokens banded together probably. Hey look, they fixed banding!

89003: Spectral Searchlight.author: Mode
89003: Spectral Searchlight.text_parsed:
"This is NOT strictly worse than the ingot simply because of the multiplayer thing. You just have to remember it can do that:Lost a 2HG game because my partner was short a land and I forgot it says 'Target player'" -- Dragon_Nut

It does not say "target player" actually, the ability is untargeted.
This means it works even on someone wearing an Ivory Mask, which is advantageous in general since you can use it on you or your teammate even then. Would have been better against your opponent as well when Mana Burn still existed.
I wish it was targeted though, since it would work very nicely with Dormant Gomazoa then.
89003: Spectral Searchlight.text_posted:

It does [i]not[/i] say "target player" actually, the ability is untargeted.
This means it works even on someone wearing an [autocard]Ivory Mask[/autocard], which is advantageous in general since you can use it on you or your teammate even then. Would have been better against your opponent as well when Mana Burn still existed.
I wish it was targeted though, since it would work very nicely with [autocard]Dormant Gomazoa[/autocard] then.

89006: Boros Fury-Shield.author: the-unbeliever
89006: Boros Fury-Shield.text_parsed:
Combine with any pump spell for massive fun. "Oh, you're attacking me with your 1/1? Let me put some Giant Growth on that for you. Now you take five damage for my four mana." Even better with bigger creatures/bigger pumps. "Oh, you're hitting me with your 9/9? Let me put Might of Oaks on that for you. Here you go, 16 damage to the face."

Also completely nullifies the mighty Baneslayer Angel - block with your flying creature with five power or more, Boros Fury-Shield the damage, and bam, opponent takes five from this card, BA didn't do any damage so neither first strike nor lifelink matter, and they have a dead angel. Anything that can take down that broken card while doing damage and just needs to be combo'd with a 5/* in the air, for three mana, is okay in my book.

89006: Boros Fury-Shield.author: achilleselbow
89006: Boros Fury-Shield.text_parsed: This card is amazing. A lot of people don't read it carefully and assume it deals damage equal to the amount of damage prevented. In fact, it deals damage equal to the creature's power, at Instant speed. Basicaly a Soul's Fire played on an opponent's creature. That means you can kill your opponent immediately after the declare blockers step, before damage resolution. There have been many times when I thought I was swinging for the win when we were both down to around 6 life, only to have this played on my Gleancrawler. My friend thought that meant it was a draw, but I was a good enough sport to correct him.

89006: Boros Fury-Shield.author: Asmodi0000
89006: Boros Fury-Shield.text_parsed:
A nasty spell that's won me a few games in an almost insulting manner. Letting my opponent build up a huge creature just to turn its own power against them might be a bit mean, but I just reassure myself by remembering that my opponent was trying to hit me with all that damage.

It's also nice because my opponents tend to second guess themselves, which often makes this like a virtual holy day for as long as I can bluff them into thinking I have it.

Interestingly enough, I have used this on my own creature once. I was low on life and attacking, and my opponent cast Divine Deflection. In order to save my life, I cast this on my own creature, and thankfully had enough white and colorless mana open to avoid killing myself.

I guess thats what you call a win-win card.

89009: Moldervine Cloak.author: Justice1337
89009: Moldervine Cloak.text_parsed:
Strange to see so few comments when this card is so highly rated.

This is one of my all-stars in my Umbra Mystic, Enchantress EDH deck. It's along the same lines as Rancor, in that it's recurrable and thus works really well as a Totem Armor. It only costs a draw every time you want to recur it, and it costs a little more to play. However, it's a bit better than the abilities provided by Rancor, and the possibility of recursion is usually enough to deter your opponents from trying to resolve your creatures with removal and sweeps, which is the point.

Overall, this is a great card, an aura that overcomes a lot of the weaknesses that auras usually carry.

89011: Pollenbright Wings.author: majinara
89011: Pollenbright Wings.text_parsed:
Most of the time, this card ain't really worth it. Why? Well, what would need to happen to make this card good:

- you'd need a creature with a high power, since else you wouldn't get enough tokens to justify this cards high manacost
- the creature must be able to attack (no moat or pacifism effects)
- the creature must be unblocked
- the creature must survive (no bounce, destroy or steal creature effectse)
- the enchantment must survive (no flicker effects on the creature, no steal enchantment or disenchant effect)
- the creature must deal damage to the player (no prevent damage effects)

And then you get some tokens. And then the card is still mediocre. It would only be good, if you'd hit a player several times with the enchanted creature. But if you are able to hit a player several times with a big creatures, then you won anyway, so what would you need this enchant for?

In short:
Fun stuff for some casual token deck, but most of the time a waste of mana and cards.

89011: Pollenbright Wings.author: Wizard-of-the-Toast
89011: Pollenbright Wings.text_parsed:
The cmc is high, but I am trying this card in my Rith, the Awakener EDH deck because it has good synergy with a lot of other cards in my deck. Just focussing on attaching it to Rith, it can help overcome one of Rith's weaknesses: when the battlefield is lacking many non-land permanents Rith can't produce many tokens. Attaching this to Rith (or another fatty) gives Rith's ability a lot more green on the field e.g. attached to Rith it would produce 6 tokens, then triggering her ability and choosing green gives you 8 more for a total of 14, while without Pollenbright she'd only make one token. With the well known token doublers the difference is even more noticeable i.e. 42 saprolings vs 4.
Expensive sure, but not worth dumping automatically.

89011: Pollenbright Wings.author: blurrymadness
89011: Pollenbright Wings.text_parsed:
Gives your fatty evasion and gives you blockers. Best used on a hexproof creatures; the best being Plated Slagwurm, Thrun, and Troll Ascetic, all of which are hard to kill (toughness, regen), the hexproof helps with most aura issues, and all of which lack evasion.

Things like that make it so you'll reliably get your saps and helps your damage get to the "red zone." You'd usually want something else, but it does work well enough with them.

89017: Dark Heart of the Wood.author: DrJack
89017: Dark Heart of the Wood.text_parsed:
"Dark Heart was the very first multicolored (or "gold") non-creature card."

It was also the first ever multicolored card with an opposing pair of colors. We were thrilled to see this back when The Dark came out in 1994, as it gave us hope that the Wizards would continue to print more multicolored spells other than just creatures. As we all know, our hopes were fulfilled.

Dark Heart of the Woods is an example of the Wizards getting a card right the first time. Zuran Orb came later, and was just silly overpowered. I think the "Dark Heart" is an underrated card. Be sure to check out its original art from The Dark... and also look at it side-by-side with Safe Haven. :-)

89021: Shambling Shell.author: Akromar
89021: Shambling Shell.text_parsed:
The new rules made it so combat Damage doesn't use the stack anymore. It used to be that You could block with this guy, have him deal his combat damage to whatever he's blocking, and then use his ability to pump up another creature.

After the change this card is much worse now to be totally honest. if you're consistently dredging him up, you're basically paying 3 mana to mill yourself by 3, and you skip your draw step. terrible for card advantage, and you get very little benefit overall. Might be redeemable if you're running a Savra, Queen of the Golgari
