89115: Razia's Purification.author: CeremonialBathory
89115: Razia's Purification.text_parsed: @vsasntore: Protection from White nor Protection from Red would stop this card. Protection only stops damage, enchanting/equipping, blocking and targeting. This card does none of these. The permanents are chosen (bypassing targeting) and then sacrificed (bypassing damage and indestructibility). However, Tajuru Preserver would allow you to completely bypass this spell's effects because it interacts specifically with sacrifice.

89116: Doubling Season.author: Mode
89116: Doubling Season.text_parsed:
A very lovely Johnny card.
It's even more interesting since it can deal with loyality counters on Planeswalkers. Ajani Goldmane and Sarkhan Vol are currently the most fun fellows for this card - two Serra Avatar tokens or eight 4/4 Dragon flyers and my Planeswalker stays on the field with 2 loyality counters nonetheless? Yes, please.

And already before those got introduced, you had fun times playing this card with other counter and/or token heavy cards, such as Pentavus, Sekki, Seasons' Guide or Lightning Coils.
Cards dealing with Charge Counters also do fine with this enchantment, such as Darksteel Reactor, although i wouldn't advise playing these in a general Doubling Season deck.
Simple token generating spells like Beacon of Creation or Call of the Herd also do a job, as well as Arcbound creatures with Modular or Simic creatures with Graft, Hydra and Fungus creatures or those with Devour - especially Mycoloth since he also produces tokens as well.

And if you're looking for a effect-related creature, try out Gilder Bairn (which in conjunction with this enchantment does an even better job.

Yet i can't remember players being permanents, therefore no, cards dealing with poison counters are pretty much the only thing that won't work with this card, Jokergius.

89116: Doubling Season.author: Karrod
89116: Doubling Season.text_parsed:
Doubling season + Disciple of the Vault + Spawning pit + dross scorpion + gilded lotus = infinite damage.

1) Tap gilded lotus for 3 mana
2) Sacrifice any artifact creature besides dross golem.
a) Gilded lotus untaps so you may tap it again
b) Spawning pit gets 2 counters on it
3) tap gilded lotus for mana again
4) Remove 2 counters on spawning pit to put 2 creatures into play.
5) Sacrifice 1 of them to put 2 charge counters on spawning pit and untap gilded lotus.
6) repeat.

Things to remember: Tokens do hit the graveyard once before disappearing from existence. Every time you sacrifice a token your opponent takes 1 damage. Even without disciple of the vault, you still get infinite 2/2 creatures because every time you sacrifice 1, you get 2 and you only need to sacrifice one of those to get another 2 more out.

I hope that works aha

89116: Doubling Season.author: professornutbutter
89116: Doubling Season.text_parsed:
@ gamer09631: This is a good idea. My question is, are you sure the growth will be exponential like you propose? Or would it be linear? I would assume the latter, so instead of 8 (2^3) tokens on the second turn after Footsteps is played, you'd get 6 (2 x 3), and then instead of 2048 (2^11) on the third turn you'd get 18 (2 x 9), etc. etc.

I could be wrong of course, but it just seems to me that they'd each apply their effect separately (linear) and not build on the previous effect (exponential). Does anybody know exactly what would happen here? And if you do know, how do you know? Has anybody tried this combo on MTGO for example?

89116: Doubling Season.author: drp527
89116: Doubling Season.text_parsed:
A couple of corrections: first, as to the case of having more than one in play at once, Wizards has already provided a ruling for this:
10/1/2005 If there are two Doubling Seasons on the battlefield, then the number of tokens or counters is four times the original number. If there are three on the battlefield, then the number of tokens or counters is eight times the original number.
The reason behind this, I believe, is that while the abilities TRY to happen simultaneously, they have to use the stack so one will go first. Once that happens, the second one will now be modifying a new number, and there's no reason it wouldn't update to double the new amount instead. Second, I believe the ruling with planeswalkers is that they'll come into play with twice the number of counters with a Season in play, but that their abilities that add counters are unaffected. This is because the addition of a counter is the COST of the ability, and Doubling Season only triggers if an EFFECT would place a counter on a permanent you control.

Once that happens, the second one will now be modifying a new number, and there's no reason it wouldn't update to double the new amount instead. Second, I believe the ruling with planeswalkers is that they'll come into play with twice the number of counters with a Season in play, but that their abilities that add counters are unaffected. This is because the addition of a counter is the COST of the ability, and Doubling Season only triggers if an EFFECT would place a counter on a permanent you control.

89116: Doubling Season.author: Daikoru
89116: Doubling Season.text_parsed:
Play this with Fungus that uses Spore Counters. Not only are they cheap to summon and the same color of Doubling Season, they also get a perfect synergy with spore counters and saproling tokens!

I simply love this card! The possibilities are infinite and you can pretty much do everything with the right cards, like dealing huge direct damage (Magma mine), gaining huge ammount of life and keeping it (Eternity Vessel), removing the whole board of the opponent (Recantation), multiplying really fast a creature of your choice (Soul Foundry) or simply winning the game through a win condition that uses counters (Darksteel Reactor, Chance Encounter and Helix Pinnacle). This is the perfect card for what I want as a main deck!

A list of useful counters types that are used for multiple effects: Quest, Charge, Versel and Divinity. Planeswalkers with their Loyalty counters are also great. Graft, Modular, Level up, Vanish and Devour are also great keyword abilities with Doubling Season.

89116: Doubling Season.author: Artscrafter
89116: Doubling Season.text_parsed:
I'm with the people who rage at seeing this card mentioned everywhere, so let's just haul out the list and be done with it.

I can't paste actual URLs in here without them getting messed up by the formatter, so here are a couple of simple searches you can run if you want to find just about every card this works well with:
1. Include "token". Exclude "nontoken".
2. Include "counter". Exclude "spell", "countered", and "suspend". (And possibly a few others based on your taste, like "cumulative upkeep" and such.)

These cards do not need to be cross-referenced back to this one. You get more tokens/counters, we get it. I would not call this sort of thing a combo because this effect is no more or less than exactly what this card does.

I'm willing to consider things to be combos if you can get an effect with this that you normally couldn't. For example, any creature + Splinter Twin + this = you get two copies and only have to exile one of them.

89116: Doubling Season.text_parsed:
I hate this card. Not because it's an awesome card; not because it's effect is lame or something i don't like; no. The only reason I hate this card is that every nub on this site posts Doubling season as part of a combo thinking that it somehow enhances the combo or is an original thought.

here's a hint. EVERY TOKEN OR COUNTER STYLE CARD CAN BENEFIT FROM THIS. Done. That's the only post we need about it. Besides, if you need doubling season to pull off your combo, you may as well say you need baneslayers or jace's to do it. It's pretty much the same idea. It's an awesome card, and combos are only awesome because it's an awesome card. There's no creativity in taking an awesome card and saying "hey this plus some mediocre card makes that card good!"

Further, by the time you cast this (turn 3-4) you may have wasted precious time. An excellent card no doubt, but people need to leave it on the shelf now and then and realize that despite being awesome it doesn't belong in every counter and token deck. if you need it to make a combo, the combo sucks. A deck needs only put these in it (assuming the proper token/counter reliance) to improve. It doesn't need sick combos because there's no point! It's already awesome! You can't polish polish, or at least, there's no point.

Let awesome be awesome and build combos out of combo cards.

89116: Doubling Season.author: Philbo_the_Happy_Halfling
89116: Doubling Season.text_parsed:
My impossible combo: Precursor Golem + Doubling Season + Rite of Replication + Xenograft + some splicers. (Preferrably Maul Splicer or Master Splicer)

So Xenograft makes everything you control the creature type of your choice in addition to whatever else it is. Choose Golem. Precursor Golem copies any spell that targets a golem for each golem you control. Doubling Season doubles that number.
With the Kicker we're talking ten token copies of every creature you control PLUS all of the golem tokens that the Precursor Golems and splicers bring in with them.

Now all you need is Aceticism to keep Unsummon from becomming Wrath of God.

Oh yeah, throw in Coat of Arms for extra fun.

89116: Doubling Season.author: MrBarrelRoll
89116: Doubling Season.text_parsed:
Rite of Replication + Opalescence + Doubling Season.

Kick the Rite targeting the Season. You put 10 Doubling Season tokens into play, each as a 5/5 creature. Now that you have 11 doubling seasons, any card that makes tokens or uses counters suddenly does 2048x what it used to do.

Say that you then cast another Rite, producing an additional 10240 Doubling Seasons. This means everything from then on is multiplied by 2^10251, which is around 7*10^3085, or a 7 followed by 3085 zeros. Then, say you play a Khalni Garden. I'm pretty sure this causes the universe to fill with plant tokens, which causes it to condense under its own mass. Congrats, you just started the next Big Bang!
89116: Doubling Season.text_posted:
[autocard]Rite of Replication[/autocard] + [autocard]Opalescence[/autocard] + [autocard]Doubling Season[/autocard].

Kick the Rite targeting the Season. You put 10 Doubling Season tokens into play, each as a 5/5 creature. Now that you have 11 doubling seasons, any card that makes tokens or uses counters suddenly does 2048x what it used to do.

Say that you then cast another Rite, producing an additional 10240 Doubling Seasons. This means everything from then on is multiplied by 2^10251, which is around 7*10^3085, or a 7 followed by 3085 zeros. Then, say you play a [autocard]Khalni Garden[/autocard]. I'm pretty sure this causes the universe to fill with plant tokens, which causes it to condense under its own mass. Congrats, you just started the next Big Bang!

89116: Doubling Season.text_parsed:
MrBarrelRoll - "Say that you then cast another Rite, producing an additional 10240 Doubling Seasons. This means everything from then on is multiplied by 2^10251, which is around 7*10^3085, or a 7 followed by 3085 zeros."

Now just imagine that before doing this step, you played a Precursor Golem and a Xenograft (calling Golem). I'm a MATH MINOR and I have no idea how many that would give you, but it's a lot bigger than the number of particles in the universe (estimated no higher than a googol, or 10^100). Hell, the SECOND COPY beats that number.

89116: Doubling Season.author: Pinto331
89116: Doubling Season.text_parsed:
I detest the notion that Doubling Season and cards like it such as Paradox Haze and Training Grounds "combo" with anything. On they're own they do literally nothing. The only purpose they serve is to make cards you're already playing better. You know, win-more.

Maybe in some cases that's not true with these cards, like using training grounds to lower activation costs to make an actual infinite combo. But if you're not doing that then Doulbing Season combos with tokens and counters as much as Giant Growth combos with an attacking creature.
89116: Doubling Season.text_posted:
I detest the notion that Doubling Season and cards like it such as [autocard]Paradox Haze[/autocard] and [autocard]Training Grounds[/autocard] "combo" with anything.  On they're own they do [i]literally[/i] nothing.  The only purpose they serve is to make cards you're already playing better.  You know, win-more.

Maybe in some cases that's not true with these cards, like using training grounds to lower activation costs to make an actual infinite combo.  But if you're not doing that then Doulbing Season combos with tokens and counters as much as [autocard]Giant Growth[/autocard] combos with an attacking creature.

89117: Searing Meditation.author: AssKickingBoots

You can make an awfully effective burn/life gain combo deck out of this. I use it with Tamanoa, but you could combo it with about any life gaining cards. In a more carefully constructed deck, this can actually be your main offensive weapon.

95097: Forest.author: fissionessence
95097: Forest.text_parsed:
Andrew's Occasional Random Card of the Day #16 - 7/13/2011 - Forest (Ravnica)

Basic land, huh? Up until now I had basically been ignoring which version of particular cards popped up in the random feature of Gatherer. But with Forest, I think I'll have to use the 'Ravnica' prompt.

Okay, so green. Green is generally the same thing across planes—that's kind of the point of the colors in general. But each plane does have its own settings, peoples, and twists on each color. On Ravnica, of course, exist ten guilds (or at least they did exist before Dissension), and four such guilds would appreciate Forests. The Ravnica lands are unique in that they depict cityscapes which still embody the color they are meant to represent. While it's not really a 'forest' here, it's still a Forest in Magic terms, in that it is a location on this plane that is the source of green mana.

One guild that uses green mana is the Gruul, but they live in the wastes, the least 'city-ified' part of Ravnica. Unless these are ancient abandoned ruins, I couldn't imagine that the Forest here is part of the Gruul wastes.

Another guild is the Simic. I don't see a drop of water or a single lab experiment, and I believe the Simic spend most of their time inside, with much less sun than we see here.

The Golgari live in the sewers and caves underneath the city, though I'm sure they've still got their cityish civilization down there. Anyway, I'm pretty sure this is not their Forest.

Finally, the Selesnya are all about pretty forest places, balconies, and sunlight. I imagine that ray of sun is shining right down onto a Selesnya grove church.

95109: Mountain.author: allmighty_abacus
95109: Mountain.text_parsed:
I run this card in a grixis color forced draw/discard deck (think howling mine, underworld dreams, spiteful visions, megrim and wistful thinking) just for the art. It looks right at home alongside a crumbling necropolis or the other grixis basic lands. Really adds to the surreal hellscape environment of the deck. The limited, starkly contrasting coloring scheme combined with how the structures seem to tower over you from all angles is brilliant.

WotC should allow more opportunities for the artists to explore other interpretations of basic lands other than generic real-world landscapes.
95109: Mountain.text_posted:

95112: Plains.author: The_Murderauder
95112: Plains.text_parsed:
I feel the same way as Dragasm, although I'm fairly sure he was being humorous. When the Ravnica lands were first printed, they were so unlike any M:tG lands we'd seen before; they had this incredible feeling of being on an entirely new plane, rather than just a boring old picture of ANOTHER random deciduous forest, and ANOTHER beautiful snow-capped mountain. These were clearly not your average high fantasy locations.

But now that the Ravnica basic land art has been used in boxed sets and special products and whatnot, they've become just another, forgettable Magic location that we've seen literally hundreds of times before. Ah, well.
95112: Plains.text_posted:

These were clearly not your average high fantasy locations.

But now that the Ravnica basic land art has been used in boxed sets and special products and whatnot, they've become just another, forgettable Magic location that we've seen literally hundreds of times before. Ah, well.

95537: Boros Signet.author: Asmodi0000
95537: Boros Signet.text_parsed: A solid card. It provides mana fixing and next turn mana acceleration in colors that don't seem to have enough of either. While most competitive R/W decks would rather use the early turns to drop down cheap creatures, I like the signet in my casual deck that uses a lot of the higher costed creatures and cards. A turn 3 Brion Stoutarm or turn 4 Balefire Liege is not a bad deal in exchange for spending turn 2 dropping down this signet.
95537: Boros Signet.text_posted: A solid card. It provides mana fixing and next turn mana acceleration in colors that don't seem to have enough of either. While most competitive R/W decks would rather use the early turns to drop down cheap creatures, I like the signet in my casual deck that uses a lot of the higher costed creatures and cards. A turn 3 [autocard]Brion Stoutarm[/autocard] or turn 4 [autocard]Balefire Liege[/autocard] is not a bad deal in exchange for spending turn 2 dropping down this signet.
